trivia: Harenchi Gakuen was created by Go Nagai, known for his contributions to the ecchi and mecha genres.

description:
• Peranmē Holmes Ch. 1
  • Hōchōnin Ajihei Ch. 151
  • Doberman Deka Ch. 44
  • Play Ball Ch. 135
  • Neppu no Tora Ch. 3
  • Hoankan Jō Ch. 4
  • Tōdai Icchokusen Ch. 2
  • Ora Asutāda!
  • Circuit no Ōkami Ch. 77
  • Toilet Hakase Ch. 283
  • Kochikame Ch. 1 (though this is the first appearance of the long-running series by Osamu Akimoto, the actual serialized version did not appear until a few months later; see note below for why it is regarded as the first chapter*)
  • Akutare Kyojin Ch. 24
  • 1•2 no Ahho!! Ch. 37
  • Satellite no Niji Ch. 23

*While normally the pilot chapter is not regarded as part of a series, with Kochikame it was included as the first chapter in the collections (many pilot chapters are never collected or only appear in a collection of rarities by the author) and in celebrating the fortieth anniversary of the series (in the 42nd issue of 2016, mirroring the 42nd issue of 1976 where the serialization began), it was this chapter that was printed in full color, rather than the one in 42-1976.

Since Kochikame never actually numbered its chapters, there is no official chapter one, but it is likely the pilot has retroactively been made the first chapter simply because in it, Ryo-san is accompanied by Keiichi Nakagawa who would become the second most frequently appearing character in the series, whereas in the serialization he was not introduced until a few chapters in and Kinji Totsuka was Ryotsu's first companion.

As collections were much slower to come out during this era, by the time the first volume came out, Totsuka had mostly been written out of the series and Keiichi took his place, making the first chapter of the serialization relevant to readers of the early chapters while the pilot is relevant to readers of any era.
trivia: 'Kochikame' by Osamu Akimoto is considered to have started in Ch. 1, even though the actual serialized version appeared later, making it a unique case in manga history.
'Peranmē Holmes' marks the beginning of a new detective series in the manga world.

trivia: 'Hana no Keiji' is a historical manga series that ran for 26 volumes and was created by the renowned manga artist, Keiichiro Ryumon.
'Dragon Ball' by Akira Toriyama, marked by its iconic protagonist Son Goku, has had a significant impact on the shonen genre and is considered a classic in the manga world.
'Saint Seiya' known as 'Knights of the Zodiac' in the West, was one of the early manga series to be translated and published in English, gaining popularity outside of Japan.
'Kochikame' holds the Guinness World Record for the most volumes published for a single manga series, with a total of 200 volumes released over its run.
'JoJo's Bizarre Adventure' by Hirohiko Araki is known for its unique art style and storytelling, often incorporating references to Western music, fashion, and culture.

In celebration of Kochikame's 30th anniversary, many crossover tributes were made with other Shonen Jump series', past and present. Though this issue is dedicated to his crossing over into other current titles, a special issue Cho Kochikame was also released to feature other works crossing over (that is the comic advertised in the top right corner of this issue).

Most of Ryotsu's cameos in the series' published in this issue were in posters, magazines or calendars in the background, while a select few series featured him as a present character in crowd shots and a few even wrote him very specifically into their story.
trivia: Kochikame celebrated its 30th anniversary with a special chapter showcasing characters most requested by readers to return.
Eyeshield 21 reached Chapter 201 in this volume.
Majin Tantei Nōgami Neuro was on Chapter 77 in this issue.
Maison du Penguin was on Chapter 30 in this volume.
Shinsetsu Bobobōbo Bōbobo was on Chapter 36 in this issue.

*A large number of characters from other manga then-currently running in the magazine make cameos, an inverse of the 30th Kochikame anniversary special a few weeks earlier. A number of the characters only appear in this chapter and not in their respective series' chapter even including major characters like Naruto who had not been the focus of his series already for a few weeks but appears here or Jaguar Junichi whose series was missing from this issue. Though many characters appear in pictures in the background including Ichigo Kurosaki and Kakashi Hatake, only those that appear in person are credited here. Cameos were also not limited at all to just the main characters with random appearances including Blueno and Haku, who had been effectively defeated and absent from their series for over a year, and a full list of the cameos includes gags such as a tennis ball appearing (from Prince of Tennis).
trivia: 'Katekyō Hitman Reborn!' started with Chapter 116, indicating a significant amount of content before this point.

  • Majin Tantei Nōgami Neuro Ch. 166
  • Boku no Watashi no Yusha Gaku Ch. 65
  • Pyu to Fuku! Jaguar Ch. 338

Notes

In celebration of the magazine's 40th anniversary, dozens of series from the past were represented in various forms, including the cover (which was made in such a way that turning each page would reveal a slightly smaller cover representing a different decade).

Many characters appeared on the cover without appearing in the story and many of these same characters' respective series were elaborated on in the special two-part Kochikame feature that went through the history of Jump. Though there were other nods to the past such as a large double-sided poster by Yusuke Murata featuring characters from most major serials in the magazine's history, only characters from the covers are credited here and are as follows (the main cover features the only four characters from the other covers that were still in ongoing serials).

1968-1978

  • Mankichi Togawa (Otoko Ippiki Gaki-Daishō)
  • Higegojira (Harenchi Gakuen)
  • Kanō Jōji (Doberman Deka)
  • Hiroshi Kaizuka (Dokonjō Gaeru)
  • Takao Taniguchi (Play Ball)
  • Yuya Fubuki (Circuit no Ōkami)
  • Kentaro Inui (Susume!! Pirates)
  • Uno Kyūji (Astro Kyūdan)

1978-1988

  • Kinnikuman (Kinnikuman)
  • Kenshiro (Hokuto no Ken)
  • Arale Norimaki (Dr. Slump)
  • Tsurugi Momotaro (Sakigake!! Otokojuku)
  • Tsubasa Ozora (Captain Tsubasa)
  • Ryo Saeba (City Hunter)
  • Ichidō Rei, Shusse Kiyoshi, Daima Jin, Monohoshi Dai, Reietsu Gō (High School! Kimengumi)
  • Ryuji Takane (Ring ni Kakero)
  • Seiya, Saint of Pegasus (Saint Seiya)

1988-1998

  • Goku (Dragon Ball)
  • Yusuke Urameshi (Yū Yū Hakusho)
  • Dai (Dragon Quest: Dai no Daibōken)
  • Hanamichi Sakuragi (Slam Dunk)
  • Maeda Taison (Rokudenashi Blues)
  • Ai Amano (Den'ei Shōjo)
  • Jotaro Kujo (JoJo no Kimyō na Bōken)
  • Hareluya Hibino (BØY)
  • Kenshin (Rurouni Kenshin)
  • Masaru Hananakajima (Sexy Commando Gaiden: Sugoi Yo!! Masaru-san)

1998-2008

  • Monkey D. Luffy (One Piece)
  • Kankichi Ryotsu (Kochikame)
  • Pharaoh Atem (Yu-Gi-Oh!)
  • Ichigo Kurosaki (Bleach)
  • Yoh Asakura (Shaman King)
  • Naruto Uzumaki (Naruto)
  • Bobobo-bo Bo-bobo (Bobobōbo Bōbobo)
  • Light Yagami/Ryuk (Death Note)
  • Ryoma Echizen (Prince of Tennis)
  • Takeshi (Seikimatsu Leader-den Takeshi!)
  • Hikaru Shindo (Hikaru no Go)
trivia: The first chapter of Toriko is marked as Chapter 10, indicating that there were likely pilot one-shots or special chapters before the official serialization began.
Kochikame: History of Jump is a special chapter that delves into the history of Shonen Jump, showcasing creator connections and the evolution of manga over time.
Double Arts is a discontinued series, as evidenced by its relatively low chapter number of 17 compared to ongoing series in the list.
Several iconic characters such as Goku from Dragon Ball and Monkey D. Luffy from One Piece are featured in the content list, highlighting the lasting impact of these series in the manga industry.
Psyren, despite having only 31 chapters listed, is known for its genre innovation in blending elements of science fiction, action, and mystery within a shonen manga narrative.

The magazine cover was the result of a contest where readers could vote which character would appear alongside Gintoki; though the original contest presented as example covers the series' most popular villain (Takasugi), one of the series' most popular joke characters (Yamazaki) and a totally random choice (a nameless announcer that had appeared in the series), the winner proved to be none other than the second most popular character of the series, resulting in a clever attempt at subverting the popularity polls to just turn into another popularity poll. Runners up in the contest appear on the chapter cover.
trivia: The first chapter of Gintama featuring a cover with multiple characters is Chapter 490, showcasing Takasugi, Tae, Kamui, and others.

  • Shiri Kodama! (special chapter of the series from Saikyō Jump)
  • Samon-kun wa Summoner Ch. 61
  • Hinomaru Zumō Ch. 125
  • Shokugeki no Soma Ch. 195 - Wilderness Pioneer
  • Spring Weapon Number One Ch. 9
  • Ibitsu no Amalgam Ch. 10
  • Isobe Isobee Monogatari - Ukiyo wa Tsurai yo - Ch. 216

The cover depicts each of the series protagonists cosplaying as one of the Straw Hats, they are mostly evenly divided so that each of the Straw Hats has two versions (with Chopper having three and Luffy appearing as himself) but a number of the characters have ties to the characters they represent:

  • Zoro: Asta (Black Clover) and Tanjiro (Kimetsu no Yaiba) are both swordsmen, interestingly, all three fight with a different number of swords; Tanjiro uses one, Asta uses two and Zoro uses three
  • Nami: Yūna (Yuragi-sō no Yūna-san) and Sakura Teshigawara (Samon-kun wa Summoner), likely chosen because they were the closest to being female leads, Yūna is blushing due to the fact she is frequently embarrassed by others accidentally seeing or touching her ghost body and Sakura is known for being impossible to corrupt whereas Nami is more likely to corrupt someone else
  • Usopp: Saiki Kusuo (Saiki Kusuo no Psi-nan) and Zeroichi Namba (Spring Weapon Number One), both Saiki and Zeroichi are extremely powerful characters in their universe who are trying to just pretend to be normal kids whereas Usopp is known for often being one of the weakest in-universe but routinely lying about his strength and infamy to avoid conflict
  • Sanji: Izuku Midoriya (Boku no Hero Academia) and Soma Yukihira (Shokugeki no Soma), Soma and Sanji have both dedicated themselves to cooking while Izuku and Sanji both fight primarily with their legs, refusing to use their hands (for very different reasons)
  • Chopper: Shōyō Hinata (Haikyū!!), Masaharu Tsuchiya (Seshiji o Pin! to) and Emma (Yakusoku no Neverland), Chopper is often mistaken for a pet of the Straw Hats rather than a member due to his small size and cuteness while both Hinata and Tsuchiya are known for being very short in comparison to their teammates and Emma is still an eleven year-old kid
  • Robin: Gintoki Sakata (Gintama) and Isobe Isobee (Isobe Isobee Monogatari), relying on humor rather than accuracy, due likely to the lack of female protagonists, both Gintoki and Isobe are male characters from gag-oriented manga where it wouldn't be weird for them to dress as a woman (Gintoki having even been switched into a female for an arc where every cast member's gender was switched)
  • Franky: Ushio Hinomaru (Hinomaru Zumō) and Bolo (Demon's Plan), as Bolo was still a very new character, it is his red stone hand (similar to Hellboy) that makes him most fitting for Franky who is a cyborg with a very red color-scheme...meanwhile, Hinomaru and Franky have little in common though they both are rarely seen wearing pants or covering their chests (for very different reasons)
  • Brook: Rokumichi Kusaba (Ibitsu no Amalgam) and Masami Banba (Ole Golazo), both being two of the newest protagonists in the magazine at the time, Rokumichi is a perfect match for Brook due to the fact Brook is a living skeleton and more than half of Rokumichi's body is no longer human and just bones that he can grow and shape at will, Banba had barely appeared at all by this point though notably he had just (accidentally and awkwardly) seen the female protagonist's panties the previous issue and Brook is known for asking every female he meets if he can see their panties (usually getting hit instead)

description:
Contents

  • One Piece Ch. 863 - The Honorable (Cover, Color Pages)
  • Boku no Hero Academia Ch. 135 - An Unpleasant Talk (Bakugou appears on the magazine cover only)
  • Haikyuu!! Ch. 251
  • Chingiri (One Shot, Color Pages)
  • Robot × Laserbeam Ch. 6
  • The Promised Neverland Ch. 36 - Action: Part: 5
  • Kimetsu no Yaiba Ch. 59 (Color Pages)
  • Kimetsu no Yaiba Bangaihen
  • Spring Weapon Number One Ch. 26
  • Black Clover Ch. 107 - The King Of The Clover Kingdom
  • Shokugeki no Soma Ch. 212 - Visiting The Old Versus Learning The New (Color Pages)
  • Dr. Stone Ch. 8
  • Gintama Ch. 632
  • Yuragi-sō no Yūna-san Ch. 60
  • Hinomaru Zumō Ch. 142
  • Saiki Kusuo no Ψ Nan Ch. 241
  • Boku-tachi wa Benkyou ga Dekinai Ch. 12
  • Samon-kun wa Summoner Ch. 78
  • Harapeko no Marie Ch. 9
  • Poro no Ryugaku-ki Ch. 10
  • U19 Ch. 11
  • Isobe Isobee Monogatari - Ukiyo wa Tsurai yo - Ch. 233

Though it is fairly routine, historically, for double issues of the magazine to feature the entire current WSJ cast, this cover is a rather unique outlier in that most of the main cast members are on the back cover and secondary protagonists or side characters are on the main cover. Though at first glance, it may seem that it's just another general cast page, if the two covers are put together, it is clear that each character is playing janken (rock, paper, scissors) with their counterpart and reacting accordingly.

  • Luffy beats Sanji, his crew's cook (scissors > paper)
  • Deku beats a Bakugou, his rival (paper > rock)
  • Hinata beats Kageyama, his rival (paper > rock)
  • Robo beats Yozan, his rival (paper > rock)
  • Emma beats Ray, her friend (rock > scissors)
  • Tanjiro loses to Nezuko, his sister (rock < paper)
  • Zeroichi loses to Hokuto, his "friend" (scissors < rock)
  • Asta ties with Yuno, his rival (rock = rock)
  • Soma loses to Erina, his rival (rock < paper)
  • Senku beats Taiju, his friend (paper > rock)
  • Gintoki loses to Shinpachi, his employee (paper < scissors)
  • Yūna beats Fuyuzora, her love interest (scissors > paper)
  • Hinomaru beats Kunisaki, his teammate (rock > scissors)
  • Saiki loses to Nendou, his "friend" (rock < paper)
  • Yuiga loses to Fumino and Rizu, who he tutors (paper < scissors)
  • Samon loses to Sakura, his rival (rock < paper)
  • Marie beats Taiga, who she shares a body with (scissors > paper)
  • Poro beats Yuta, his friend (paper > rock)
  • Kudou beats Nanami, his friend (paper > rock)
  • Isobee loses to Nakajima, his friend (scissors < rock)
  • Boruto beats Sarada, his teammate (scissors > paper)...an odd inclusion as there was no Boruto chapter in this issue
trivia: The first chapter of 'One Piece' in this issue is Chapter 863 titled 'The Honorable', featuring a cover and color pages.
The manga 'Chingiri' is a one-shot included in this issue with color pages.
The Western comic character connections can be seen in the rock-paper-scissors outcomes provided, such as Deku beating Bakugou, similar to how paper beats rock.
The series 'Boruto' is mentioned in the rock-paper-scissors outcomes, even though there was no Boruto chapter in this particular issue.
The pilot one-shot 'Robot × Laserbeam' is featured in this issue with Chapter 6.
